text: Cell type - and stage - specific expression of the <extra_id_0> CD20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> B1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antigen correlates with the activity of a diverged octamer DNA motif present in its promoter .

The <extra_id_0> CD20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> B1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) gene encodes a B cell - specific protein involved in the regulation of human B cell proliferation and differentiation .

Studies with 5 ' deletion <extra_id_0> CD20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter - <extra_id_0> CAT <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> constructs have previously revealed two regions of the promoter between bases -186 and -280 and between bases -280 and -454 which contained positive regulatory elements .

In this study we identified a sequence element present in the most proximal region located between bases -214 and -201 , TTCTTCTAATTAA , which is important in the high constitutive expression of <extra_id_0> CD20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in mature B cells and the induction of <extra_id_0> CD20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in pre-B cells .

This sequence element was referred to as the BAT box and its deletion significantly reduced the activity of a <extra_id_0> CD20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter - <extra_id_0> CAT <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> construct in B cells .
Mobility shift assays with various mutant probes and B cell nuclear extracts demonstrated that the core sequence TAAT was essential for binding to this site .

Cross competition experiments with an octamer sequence from the Ig heavy chain promoter , the BAT box , and a TA-rich sequence present in the <extra_id_0> CD21 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter revealed that all three sequences bound the same nuclear proteins suggesting that the BAT box binding proteins were <extra_id_0> Oct-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Oct-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Southwestern blotting and UV cross-linking studies confirmed that the BAT box binding proteins were <extra_id_0> Oct-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Oct-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

The affinity of the BAT box binding proteins for the BAT box was approximately 25-fold less than for the octamer sequence and the BAT box binding proteins dissociated from the BAT box 10-fold more rapidly than from the octamer sequence .

Despite this lower affinity , a trimer of the BAT box sequence was as efficiently transactivated by an <extra_id_0> Oct-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression vector as was a trimer of the octamer sequence in HeLa cells .

The BAT box and <extra_id_0> Oct-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> were also implicated in the induction of <extra_id_0> CD20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the pre-B cell line , PB-697 , via phorbol esters .

The induction of <extra_id_0> CD20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA was temporally associated with induction of <extra_id_0> Oct-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA and a BAT box - deleted <extra_id_0> CD20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - CAT construct , in contrast to the wild type , was poorly induced by phorbol esters .

Together these results suggest that the BAT box binding proteins are important in the B cell specific expression of <extra_id_0> CD20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and perhaps <extra_id_0> CD21 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
